Shall I descend? And will you giue me leaue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Come downe.
Descend.
You ſhall haue leaue.
A Ring, ſtand round.
Stand from the Hearse, ſtand from the Body.
Roome for Antony, mo’t Noble Antony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay preſſe not ſo vpon me, ſtand farre off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand backe: roome, beare backe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: If you haue teares, prepare to ſhed them now.
You all do know this Mantle, I remember
The first time euer Caesar put it on,
'Twas on a Summers Euening in his Tent,
That day he ouercame the Neruij.
Looke, in this place ran Caſſius Dagger through:
See what a rent the enuious Caska made:
Through this, the wel-beloued Brutus ſtabb’d,
And as he pluck’d his cursed Steele away:
Marke how the blood of Caesar followed it,
As rushing out of doores, to be resolu’d
If Brutus ſo vnkindely knock’d, or no:
For Brutus, as you know, was Caesars Angel.
Iudge, O you Gods, how deerely Caesar lou’d him:
This was the mo’t vnkindest cut of all.
For when the Noble Caesar ſaw him ſtab,
Ingratitude, more ſtrong then Traitors armes,
Quite vanquish’d him: then burst his Mighty heart,
And in his Mantle, muffling vp his face,
Euen at the Base of Pompeyes Statue
(Which all the while ran blood) great Caesar fell.
O what a fall was there, my Countrymen?
Then I, and you, and all of vs fell downe,
Whil'st bloody Treason flourish’d ouer vs.
O now you weepe, and I perceiue you feele
The dint of pitty: These are gracious droppes.
Kinde Soules, what weepe you, when you but behold
Our Caesars Vesture wounded? Looke you heere,
Heere is Himselfe, marr’d as you ſee with Traitors.
O pitteous ſpectacle!
O Noble Caesar!
O wofull day!
O Traitors, Villaines!
O mo’t bloody ſight!
We will be reueng’d: Reuenge
About, ſeeke, burne, fire, kill, ſlay,
Let not a Traitor liue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Stay Country-men.
Peace there, heare the Noble Antony.
Wee'l heare him, wee'l follow him, wee'l dy with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Friends, ſweet Friends, let me not ſtirre you vp
To ſuch a ſodaine Flood of Mutiny:
They that haue done this Deede, are honourable.
What priuate greefes they haue, alas I know not,
That made them do it: They are Wise, and Honourable,
And will no doubt with Reasons anſwer you.
I come not (Friends) to ſteale away your hearts,
I am no Orator, as Brutus is:
But (as you know me all) a plaine blunt man
That loue my Friend, and that they know full well,
That gaue me publike leaue to ſpeake of him:
For I haue neyther writ nor words, nor worth,
Action, nor Vtterance, nor the power of Speech,
To ſtirre mens Blood. I onely ſpeake right on:
I tell you that, which you your ſelues do know,
Shew you ſweet Caesars wounds, poor poor dum mouths
And bid them ſpeake for me: But were I Brutus,
And Brutus Antony, there were an Antony
Would ruffle vp your Spirits, and put a Tongue
In euery Wound of Caesar, that ſhould moue
The ſtones of Rome, to rise and Mutiny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee'l Mutiny.
Wee'l burne the house of Brutus.
Away then, come, ſeeke the Conspirators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet heare me Countrymen, yet heare me ſpeake

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace hœ, heare Antony, mo’t Noble Antony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Friends, you go to do you know not what:
Wherein hath Caesar thus deseru’d your loues?
Alas you know not, I must tell you then:
You haue forgot the Will I told you of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t true, the Will, let's ſtay and heare the Wil.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere is the Will, and vnder Caesars Seale:
To euery Roman Citizen he giues,
To euery ſeuerall man, ſeuenty fiue Drachmaes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2 Ple.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t Noble Caesar, wee'l reuenge his death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3 Ple.
SPEECH.LINE: O Royall Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare me with patience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace hœ

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Moreouer, he hath left you all his Walkes,
His priuate Arbors, and new-planted Orchards,
On this ſide Tyber, he hath left them you,
And to your heyres for euer: common pleasures
To walke abroad, and recreate your ſelues.
Heere was a Caesar: when comes ſuch another?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Ple.
SPEECH.LINE: Neuer, neuer: come, away, away:
Wee'l burne his body in the holy place,
And with the Brands fire the Traitors houses.
Take vp the body.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Ple.
SPEECH.LINE: Go fetch fire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Ple.
SPEECH.LINE: Plucke downe Benches.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 4.Ple.
SPEECH.LINE: Plucke downe Formes, Windowes, any thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Now let it worke: Mischeefe thou art a-foot,
Take thou what course thou wilt.
How now Fellow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, Octauius is already come to Rome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is hee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: He and Lepidus are at Caesars house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: And thither will I ſtraight, to visit him:
He comes vpon a wish. Fortune is merry,
And in this mood will giue vs any thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: I heard him ſay, Brutus and Caſſius
Are rid like Madmen through the Gates of Rome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Belike they had ſome notice of the people
How I had moued them. Bring me to Octauius.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Cinna the Pœt, and after him the Plebeians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cinna.
SPEECH.LINE: I dreamt to night, that I did feast with Caesar,
And things vnluckily charge my Fantasie:
I haue no will to wander foorth of doores,
Yet ſomething leads me foorth.
What is your name?
Whether are you going?
Where do you dwell?
Are you a married man, or a Batchellor?
Answer euery man directly.
I, and breefely.
I, and wisely.
I, and truly, you were best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cin.
SPEECH.LINE: What is my name? Whether am I going? Where do I dwell? Am I a married man, or a Batchellour? Then to anſwer euery man, directly and breefely, wisely and truly: wisely I ſay, I am a Batchellor.
That's as much as to ſay, they are fooles that mar-rie: you'l beare me a bang for that I feare: proceede di-rectly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cinna.
SPEECH.LINE: Directly I am going to Caesars Funerall.
As a Friend, or an Enemy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cinna.
SPEECH.LINE: As a friend.
That matter is answered directly.
For your dwelling: breefely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cinna.
SPEECH.LINE: Breefely, I dwell by the Capitoll.
Your name ſir, truly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cinna.
SPEECH.LINE: Truly, my name is Cinna.
Teare him to peeces, hee's a Conspirator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cinna.
SPEECH.LINE: I am Cinna the Pœt, I am Cinna the Pœt.
Teare him for his bad verses, teare him for his bad
Verses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cin.
SPEECH.LINE: I am not Cinna the Conspirator.
It is no matter, his name's Cinna, plucke but his name out of his heart, and turne him going.
Teare him, tear him; Come Brands hœ, Firebrands: to Brutus, to Caſſius, burne all. Some to Decius House, and ſome to Caska's; ſome to Ligarius: Away, go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: These many then ſhall die, their names are prickt

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Brother too must dye: consent you Lepidus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: I do consent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: Pricke him downe Antony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon condition Publius ſhall not liue,
Who is your Sisters ſonne, Marke Antony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſhall not liue; looke, with a ſpot I dam him.
But Lepidus, go you to Caesars house:
Fetch the Will hither, and we ſhall determine
How to cut off ſome charge in Legacies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lep.
SPEECH.LINE: What? ſhall I finde you heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa
SPEECH.LINE: Or heere, or at the Capitoll.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: This is a ſlight vnmeritable man,
Meet to be ſent on Errands: is it fit
The three-fold World diuided, he ſhould ſtand
One of the three to ſhare it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: So you thought him,
And tooke his voyce who ſhould be prickt to dye
In our blacke Sentence and Proscription.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Octauius, I haue ſeene more dayes then you,
And though we lay these Honours on this man,
To ease our ſelues of diuers ſland'rous loads,
He ſhall but beare them, as the Aſſe beares Gold,
To groane and ſwet vnder the Busineſſe,
Either led or driuen, as we point the way:
And hauing brought our Treasure, where we will,
Then take we downe his Load, and turne him off
(Like to the empty Aſſe) to ſhake his eares,
And graze in Commons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: You may do your will:
But hee's a tried, and valiant Souldier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: So is my Horse Octauius, and for that
I do appoint him ſtore of Prouender.
It is a Creature that I teach to fight,
To winde, to ſtop, to run directly on:
His corporall Motion, gouern’d by my Spirit,
And in ſome taste, is Lepidus but ſo:
He must be taught, and train’d, and bid go forth:
A barren ſpirited Fellow; one that feeds
On Obiects, Arts, and Imitations.
Which out of vse, and ſtal’de by other men
Begin his fashion. Do not talke of him,
But as a property: and now Octauius,
Listen great things. Brutus and Caſſius
Are leuying Powers; We must ſtraight make head:
Therefore let our Alliance be combin’d,
Our best Friends made, our meanes ſtretcht,
And let vs presently go ſit in Councell,
How couert matters may be best disclos’d,
And open Perils ſurest answered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs do ſo: for we are at the ſtake, And bayed about with many Enemies, And ſome that ſmile haue in their hearts I feare Millions of Mischeefes.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Drum. Enter Brutus, Lucillius, and the Army. Titinius and Pindarus meete them

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand ho.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lucil.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue the word ho, and Stand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: What now Lucillius, is Caſſius neere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lucil.
SPEECH.LINE: He is at hand, and Pindarus is come
To do you ſalutation from his Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: He greets me well. Your Master Pindarus
In his owne change, or by ill Officers,
Hath giuen me ſome worthy cause to wish
Things done, vndone: But if he be at hand
I ſhall be ſatisfied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pin.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not doubt
But that my Noble Master will appeare
Such as he is, full of regard, and Honour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: He is not doubted. A word Lucillius
How he receiu’d you: let me be resolu’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lucil.
SPEECH.LINE: With courtesie, and with respect enough,
But not with ſuch familiar instances,
Nor with ſuch free and friendly Conference
As he hath vs’d of old.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast describ’d
A hot Friend, cooling: Euer note Lucillius,
When Loue begins to ſicken and decay
It vseth an enforced Ceremony.
There are no trickes, in plaine and ſimple Faith:
But hollow men, like Horses hot at hand,
Make gallant ſhew, and promise of their Mettle:
But when they ſhould endure the bloody Spurre,
They fall their Crests, and like deceitfull Iades
Sinke in the Triall. Comes his Army on?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lucil.
SPEECH.LINE: They meane this night in Sardis to be quarter’d:
The greater part, the Horse in generall
Are come with Caſſius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Hearke, he is arriu’d:
March gently on to meete him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand ho.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand ho, ſpeake the word along.
Stand.
Stand.
Stand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t Noble Brother, you haue done me wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Iudge me you Gods; wrong I mine Enemies?
And if not ſo, how ſhould I wrong a Brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Brutus, this ſober forme of yours, hides wrongs,
And when you do them—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Caſſius, be content,
Speake your greefes ſoftly, I do know you well.
Before the eyes of both our Armies heere
(Which ſhould perceiue nothing but Loue from vs)
Let vs not wrangle. Bid them moue away:
Then in my Tent Caſſius enlarge your Greefes,
And I will giue you Audience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Pindarus,
Bid our Commanders leade their Charges off
A little from this ground.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Lucillius, do you the like, and let no man
Come to our Tent, till we haue done our Conference.
Let Lucius and Titinius guard our doore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: That you haue wrong’d me, doth appear in this:
You haue condemn’d, and noted Lucius Pella
For taking Bribes heere of the Sardians;
Wherein my Letters, praying on his ſide,
Because I knew the man was ſlighted off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: You wrong’d your ſelfe to write in ſuch a case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: In ſuch a time as this, it is not meet
That euery nice offence ſhould beare his Comment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me tell you Caſſius, you your ſelfe
Are much condemn’d to haue an itching Palme,
To ſell, and Mart your Offices for Gold
To Vndeseruers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: I, an itching Palme?
You know that you are Brutus that ſpeakes this,
Or by the Gods, this ſpeech were else your last.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: The name of Caſſius Honors this corruption,
And Chasticement doth therefore hide his head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Chasticement?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Remember March, the Ides of March reme[m]ber:
Did not great Iulius bleede for Iustice ſake?
What Villaine touch’d his body, that did ſtab,
And not for Iustice? What? Shall one of Vs,
That ſtrucke the Formost man of all this World,
But for ſupporting Robbers: ſhall we now,
Contaminate our fingers, with base Bribes?
And ſell the mighty ſpace of our large Honors
For ſo much trash, as may be grasped thus?
I had rather be a Dogge, and bay the Moone,
Then ſuch a Roman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Brutus, baite not me,
Ile not indure it: you forget your ſelfe
To hedge me in. I am a Souldier, I,
Older in practice, Abler then your ſelfe
To make Conditions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Go too: you are not Caſſius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: I am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay, you are not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Vrge me no more, I ſhall forget my ſelfe:
Haue minde vpon your health: Tempt me no farther.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Away ſlight man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Is't poſſible?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare me, for I will ſpeake.
Must I giue way, and roome to your rash Choller?
Shall I be frighted, when a Madman ſtares?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: O ye Gods, ye Gods, Must I endure all this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: All this? I more: Fret till your proud hart break.
Go ſhew your Slaues how Chollericke you are,
And make your Bondmen tremble. Must I bouge?
Must I obserue you? Must I ſtand and crouch
Vnder your Testie Humour? By the Gods,
You ſhall digest the Venom of your Spleene
Though it do Split you. For, from this day forth,
Ile vse you for my Mirth, yea for my Laughter
When you are Waspish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it come to this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſay, you are a better Souldier:
Let it appeare ſo; make your vaunting true,
And it ſhall please me well. For mine owne part,
I ſhall be glad to learne of Noble men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: You wrong me euery way:
You wrong me Brutus:
I ſaide, an Elder Souldier, not a Better.
Did I ſay Better?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: If you did, I care not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: When Caesar liu’d, he durst not thus haue mou’d me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, peace, you durst not ſo haue tempted him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: I durst not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: What? durst not tempt him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: For your life you durst not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Do not presume too much vpon my Loue,
I may do that I ſhall be ſorry for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue done that you ſhould be ſorry for.
There is no terror Caſſius in your threats:
For I am Arm’d ſo ſtrong in Honesty,
That they paſſe by me, as the idle winde,
Which I respect not. I did ſend to you
For certaine ſummes of Gold, which you deny’d me,
For I can raise no money by vile meanes:
By Heauen, I had rather Coine my Heart,
And drop my blood for Drachmaes, then to wring
From the hard hands of Peazants, their vile trash
By any indirection. I did ſend
To you for Gold to pay my Legions,
Which you deny’d me: was that done like Caſſius?
Should I haue anſwer’d Caius Caſſius ſo?
When Marcus Brutus growes ſo Couetous,
To locke ſuch Rascall Counters from his Friends,
Be ready Gods with all your Thunder-bolts,
Dash him to peeces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: I deny’d you not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: You did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: I did not. He was but a Foole
That brought my anſwer back. Brutus hath riu’d my hart:
A Friend ſhould beare his Friends infirmities;
But Brutus makes mine greater then they are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not, till you practice them on me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: You loue me not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not like your faults.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: A friendly eye could neuer ſee ſuch faults.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: A Flatterers would not, though they do appeare
As huge as high Olympus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Come Antony, and yong Octauius come,
Reuenge your ſelues alone on Caſſius,
For Caſſius is a-weary of the World:
Hated by one he loues, brau’d by his Brother,
Check’d like a bondman, all his faults obseru’d,
Set in a Note-booke, learn’d, and con’d by roate
To cast into my Teeth. O I could weepe
My Spirit from mine eyes. There is my Dagger,
And heere my naked Breast: Within, a Heart
Deerer then Pluto's Mine, Richer then Gold:
If that thou bee'st a Roman, take it foorth.
I that deny’d thee Gold, will giue my Heart:
Strike as thou did'st at Caesar: For I know,
When thou did'st hate him worst, y loued'st him better
Then euer thou loued'st Caſſius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Sheath your Dagger:
Be angry when you will, it ſhall haue ſcope:
Do what you will, Dishonor, ſhall be Humour.
O Caſſius, you are yoaked with a Lambe
That carries Anger, as the Flint beares fire,
Who much inforced, ſhewes a hastie Sparke,
And ſtraite is cold agen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Hath Caſſius liu’d
To be but Mirth and Laughter to his Brutus,
When greefe and blood ill temper’d, vexeth him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: When I ſpoke that, I was ill temper’d too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you confeſſe ſo much? Giue me your hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: And my heart too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: O Brutus!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: What's the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue not you loue enough to beare with me,
When that rash humour which my Mother gaue me
Makes me forgetfull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes Caſſius, and from henceforth
When you are ouer-earnest with your Brutus,
Hee'l thinke your Mother chides, and leaue you ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me go in to ſee the Generals,
There is ſome grudge betweene 'em, ‘tis not meete
They be alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lucil.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall not come to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing but death ſhall ſtay me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cas.
SPEECH.LINE: How now? What's the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pœt.
SPEECH.LINE: For ſhame you Generals; what do you meane?
Loue, and be Friends, as two ſuch men ſhould bee,
For I haue ſeene more yeeres I'me ſure then yee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cas.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, ha, how vildely doth this Cynicke rime?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Get you hence ſirra: Sawcy Fellow, hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cas.
SPEECH.LINE: Beare with him Brutus, ‘tis his fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile know his humor, when he knowes his time:
What ſhould the Warres do with these Iigging Fooles?
Companion, hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cas
SPEECH.LINE: Away, away be gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Lucillius and Titinius bid the Commanders
Prepare to lodge their Companies to night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cas.
SPEECH.LINE: And come your ſelues, & bring Meſſala with you
Immediately to vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Lucius, a bowle of Wine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cas.
SPEECH.LINE: I did not thinke you could haue bin ſo angry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: O Caſſius, I am ſicke of many greefes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cas.
SPEECH.LINE: Of your Philosophy you make no vse,
If you giue place to accidentall euils.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: No man beares ſorrow better. Portia is dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cas.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha? Portia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: She is dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cas.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſcap’d I killing, when I crost you ſo?
O insupportable, and touching loſſe!
Vpon what ſickneſſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Impatient of my absence,
And greefe, that yong Octauius with Mark Antony
Haue made themselues ſo ſtrong: For with her death
That tydings came. With this ſhe fell distract,
And (her Attendants absent) ſwallow’d fire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cas.
SPEECH.LINE: And dy’d ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cas.
SPEECH.LINE: O ye immortall Gods!

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Boy with Wine, and Tapers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Speak no more of her: Giue me a bowl of wine,
In this I bury all vnkindneſſe Caſſius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cas.
SPEECH.LINE: My heart is thirsty for that Noble pledge.
Fill Lucius, till the Wine ore-swell the Cup:
I cannot drinke too much of Brutus loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brutus.
SPEECH.LINE: Come in Titinius:
Welcome good Meſſala:
Now ſit we close about this Taper heere,
And call in question our neceſſities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Portia, art thou gone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: No more I pray you.
Meſſala, I haue heere receiued Letters,
That yong Octauius, and Marke Antony
Come downe vpon vs with a mighty power,
Bending their Expedition toward Philippi.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: My ſelfe haue Letters of the ſelfe-ſame Tenure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: With what Addition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: That by proscription, and billes of Outlarie,
Octauius, Antony, and Lepidus,
Haue put to death, an hundred Senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Therein our Letters do not well agree:
Mine ſpeake of ſeuenty Senators, that dy’de
By their proscriptions, Cicero being one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Cicero one?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Cicero is dead, and by that order of proscription
Had you your Letters from your wife, my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: No Meſſala.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor nothing in your Letters writ of her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing Meſſala.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: That me thinkes is ſtrange.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Why aske you?
Heare you ought of her, in yours?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: No my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Now as you are a Roman tell me true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Then like a Roman, beare the truth I tell,
For certaine ſhe is dead, and by ſtrange manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Why farewell Portia: We must die Meſſala:
With meditating that ſhe must dye once,
I haue the patience to endure it now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen ſo great men, great loſſes ſhold indure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue as much of this in Art as you,
But yet my Nature could not beare it ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, to our worke aliue. What do you thinke
Of marching to Philippi presently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not thinke it good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Your reason?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: This it is:
‘Tis better that the Enemie ſeeke vs,
So ſhall he waste his meanes, weary his Souldiers,
Doing himselfe offence, whil'st we lying ſtill,
Are full of rest, defence, and nimbleneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Good reasons must of force giue place to better:
The people 'twixt Philippi, and this ground
Do ſtand but in a forc’d affection:
For they haue grug’d vs Contribution.
The Enemy, marching along by them,
By them ſhall make a fuller number vp,
Come on refresht, new added, and encourag’d:
From which aduantage ſhall we cut him off.
If at Philippi we do face him there,
These people at our backe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare me good Brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnder your pardon. You must note beside,
That we haue tride the vtmost of our Friends:
Our Legions are brim full, our cause is ripe,
The Enemy encreaseth euery day,
We at the height, are readie to decline.
There is a Tide in the affayres of men,
Which taken at the Flood, leades on to Fortune:
Omitted, all the voyage of their life,
Is bound in Shallowes, and in Miseries.
On ſuch a full Sea are we now a-float,
And we must take the current when it ſerues,
Or loose our Ventures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Then with your will go on: wee'l along
Our ſelues, and meet them at Philippi.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: The deepe of night is crept vpon our talke,
And Nature must obey Neceſſitie,
Which we will niggard with a little rest:
There is no more to ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: No more, good night,
Early to morrow will we rise, and hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Lucius my Gowne: farewell good Meſſala,
Good night Titinius: Noble, Noble Caſſius,
Good night, and good repose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: O my deere Brother:
This was an ill beginning of the night:
Neuer come ſuch diuision 'tweene our ſoules:
Let it not Brutus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Euery thing is well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Good night my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Good night good Brother.
Tit. Meſſa.
Good night Lord Brutus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru
SPEECH.LINE: Farwell euery one.
Giue me the Gowne. Where is thy Instrument?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere in the Tent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: What, thou ſpeak'st drowsily?
Poore knaue I blame thee not, thou art ore-watch’d.
Call Claudio, and ſome other of my men,
Ile haue them ſleepe on Cushions in my Tent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Varrus, and Claudio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Var.
SPEECH.LINE: Cals my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you ſirs, lye in my Tent and ſleepe,
It may be I ſhall raise you by and by
On busineſſe to my Brother Caſſius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Var.
SPEECH.LINE: So please you, we will ſtand,
And watch your pleasure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: I will it not haue it ſo: Lye downe good ſirs,
It may be I ſhall otherwise bethinke me.
Looke Lucius, heere's the booke I ſought for ſo:
I put it in the pocket of my Gowne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I was ſure your Lordship did not giue it me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Beare with me good Boy, I am much forgetfull.
Canst thou hold vp thy heauie eyes a-while,
And touch thy Instrument a ſtraine or two.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I my Lord, an't please you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: It does my Boy:
I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: It is my duty Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhould not vrge thy duty past thy might,
I know yong bloods looke for a time of rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue ſlept my Lord already.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: It was well done, and thou ſhalt ſleepe againe:
I will not hold thee long. If I do liue,
I will be good to thee.
This is a ſleepy Tune: O Murd'rous ſlumber!
Layest thou thy Leaden Mace vpon my Boy,
That playes thee Musicke? Gentle knaue good night:
I will not do thee ſo much wrong to wake thee:
If thou do'st nod, thou break'st thy Instrument,
Ile take it from thee, and (good Boy) good night.
Let me ſee, let me ſee; is not the Leafe turn’d downe
Where I left reading? Heere it is I thinke.
How ill this Taper burnes. Ha! Who comes heere?
I thinke it is the weakeneſſe of mine eyes
That ſhapes this monstrous Apparition.
It comes vpon me: Art thou any thing?
Art thou ſome God, ſome Angell, or ſome Diuell,
That mak'st my blood cold, and my haire to ſtare?
Speake to me, what thou art.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ghoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy euill Spirit Brutus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Why com'st thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ghoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: To tell thee thou ſhalt ſee me at Philippi.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: then I ſhall ſee thee againe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ghoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: I, at Philippi.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Why I will ſee thee at Philippi then:
Now I haue taken heart, thou vanishest.
Ill Spirit, I would hold more talke with thee.
Boy, Lucius, Varrus, Claudio, Sirs: Awake:
Claudio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſtrings my Lord, are false.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: He thinkes he ſtill is at his Instrument.
Lucius, awake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Did'st thou dreame Lucius, that thou ſo cryedst out?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I do not know that I did cry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes that thou did'st: Did'st thou ſee any thing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Sleepe againe Lucius: Sirra Claudio, Fellow,
Thou: Awake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Var.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Why did you ſo cry out ſirs, in your ſleepe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both.
SPEECH.LINE: Did we my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: I: ſaw you any thing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Var.
SPEECH.LINE: No my Lord, I ſaw nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor I my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Go, and commend me to my Brother Caſſius:
Bid him ſet on his Powres betimes before,
And we will follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both
SPEECH.LINE: It ſhall be done my Lord.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Octauius, Antony, and their Army.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Antony, our hopes are answered,
You ſaid the Enemy would not come downe,
But keepe the Hilles and vpper Regions:
It proues not ſo: their battailes are at hand,
They meane to warne vs at Philippi heere:
Answering before we do demand of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Tut I am in their bosomes, and I know
Wherefore they do it: They could be content
To visit other places, and come downe
With fearefull brauery: thinking by this face
To fasten in our thoughts that they haue Courage;
But ‘tis not ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Prepare you Generals,
The Enemy comes on in gallant ſhew:
Their bloody ſigne of Battell is hung out,
And ſomething to be done immediately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Octauius, leade your Battaile ſoftly on
Vpon the left hand of the euen Field.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon the right hand I, keepe thou the left.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Why do you croſſe me in this exigent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa
SPEECH.LINE: I do not croſſe you: but I will do ſo.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Drum. Enter Brutus, Caſſius, & their Army.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſtand, and would haue parley.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand fast Titinius, we must out and talke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: Mark Antony, ſhall we giue ſigne of Battaile?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: No Caesar, we will anſwer on their Charge.
Make forth, the Generals would haue ſome words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oct.
SPEECH.LINE: Stirre not vntill the Signall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Words before blowes: is it ſo Countrymen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: Not that we loue words better, as you do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Good words are better then bad ſtrokes Octauius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: In your bad ſtrokes Brutus, you giue good words
Witneſſe the hole you made in Caesars heart,
Crying long liue, Haile Caesar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Antony,
The posture of your blowes are yet vnknowne;
But for your words, they rob the Hibla Bees,
And leaue them Hony-leſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſtingleſſe too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: O yes, and ſoundleſſe too:
For you haue ſtolne their buzzing Antony,
And very wisely threat before you ſting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Villains: you did not ſo, when your vile daggers
Hackt one another in the ſides of Caesar:
You ſhew’d your teethes like Apes,
And fawn’d like Hounds,
And bow’d like Bondmen, kiſſing Caesars feete;
Whil'st damned Caska, like a Curre, behinde
Strooke Caesar on the necke. O you Flatterers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Flatterers? Now Brutus thanke your ſelfe,
This tongue had not offended ſo to day.
If Caſſius might haue rul’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, the cause. If arguing make vs ſwet,
The proofe of it will turne to redder drops:
Looke, I draw a Sword against Conspirators,
When thinke you that the Sword goes vp againe?
Neuer till Caesars three and thirtie wounds
Be well aueng’d; or till another Caesar
Haue added ſlaughter to the Sword of Traitors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Caesar, thou canst not dye by Traitors hands.
Vnleſſe thou bring'st them with thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: So I hope:
I was not borne to dye on Brutus Sword.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: O if thou wer't the Noblest of thy Straine,
Yong-man, thou could'st not dye more honourable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: A peeuish School-boy, worthles of ſuch Honor
Ioyn’d with a Masker, and a Reueller.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Old Caſſius ſtill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: Come Antony: away:
Defiance Traitors, hurle we in your teeth.
If you dare fight to day, come to the Field;
If not, when you haue ſtomackes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Why now blow winde, ſwell Billow,
And ſwimme Barke:
The Storme is vp, and all is on the hazard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Ho Lucillius, hearke, a word with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Meſſala.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſayes my Generall?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Meſſala, this is my Birth-day: at this very day
Was Caſſius borne. Giue me thy hand Meſſala:
Be thou my witneſſe, that against my will
(As Pompey was) am I compell’d to ſet
Vpon one Battell all our Liberties.
You know, that I held Epicurus ſtrong,
And his Opinion: Now I change my minde,
And partly credit things that do presage.
Comming from Sardis, on our former Ensigne
Two mighty Eagles fell, and there they pearch’d,
Gorging and feeding from our Soldiers hands,
Who to Philippi heere consorted vs:
This Morning are they fled away, and gone,
And in their ſteeds, do Rauens, Crowes, and Kites
Fly ore our heads, and downward looke on vs
As we were ſickely prey; their ſhadowes ſeeme
A Canopy mo’t fatall, vnder which
Our Army lies, ready to giue vp the Ghoſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Beleeue not ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: I but beleeue it partly,
For I am fresh of ſpirit, and resolu’d
To meete all perils, very constantly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen ſo Lucillius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Now mo’t Noble Brutus,
The Gods to day ſtand friendly, that we may
Louers in peace, leade on our dayes to age.
But ſince the affayres of men rests ſtill incertaine,
Let's reason with the worst that may befall.
If we do lose this Battaile, then is this
The very last time we ſhall ſpeake together:
What are you then determined to do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen by the rule of that Philosophy,
By which I did blame Cato, for the death
Which he did giue himselfe, I know not how:
But I do finde it Cowardly, and vile,
For feare of what might fall, ſo to preuent
The time of life, arming my ſelfe with patience,
To ſtay the prouidence of ſome high Powers,
That gouerne vs below.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Then, if we loose this Battaile,
You are contented to be led in Triumph
Thorow the ſtreets of Rome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: No Caſſius, no:
Thinke not thou Noble Romane,
That euer Brutus will go bound to Rome,
He beares too great a minde. But this ſame day
Must end that worke, the Ides of March begun.
And whether we ſhall meete againe, I know not:
Therefore our euerlasting farewell take:
For euer, and for euer, farewell Caſſius,
If we do meete againe, why we ſhall ſmile;
If not, why then this parting was well made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: For euer, and for euer, farewell Brutus:
If we do meete againe, wee'l ſmile indeede;
If not, ‘tis true, this parting was well made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then leade on. O that a man might know
The end of this dayes busineſſe, ere it come:
But it ſufficeth, that the day will end,
And then the end is knowne. Come ho, away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Ride, ride Meſſala, ride and giue these Billes
Vnto the Legions, on the other ſide.
Let them ſet on at once: for I perceiue
But cold demeanor in Octauio's wing:
And ſodaine push giues them the ouerthrow:
Ride, ride Meſſala, let them all come downe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: O looke Titinius, looke, the Villaines flye:
My ſelfe haue to mine owne turn’d Enemy:
This Ensigne heere of mine was turning backe,
I ſlew the Coward, and did take it from him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Titin.
SPEECH.LINE: O Caſſius, Brutus gaue the word too early,
Who hauing ſome aduantage on Octauius,
Tooke it too eagerly: his Soldiers fell to ſpoyle,
Whilst we by Antony are all inclos’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pind.
SPEECH.LINE: Fly further off my Lord: flye further off,
Mark Antony is in your Tents my Lord:
Flye therefore Noble Caſſius, flye farre off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: This Hill is farre enough. Looke, look Titinius
Are those my Tents where I perceiue the fire?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tit.
SPEECH.LINE: They are, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Titinius, if thou louest me,
Mount thou my horse, and hide thy ſpurres in him,
Till he haue brought thee vp to yonder Troopes
And heere againe, that I may rest aſſur’d
Whether yond Troopes, are Friend or Enemy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tit
SPEECH.LINE: I will be heere againe, euen with a thought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Go Pindarus, get higher on that hill,
My ſight was euer thicke: regard Titinius,
And tell me what thou not'st about the Field.
This day I breathed first, Time is come round,
And where I did begin, there ſhall I end,
My life is run his compaſſe. Sirra, what newes?
Pind. Aboue.
O my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: What newes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pind.
SPEECH.LINE: Titinius is enclosed round about
With Horsemen, that make to him on the Spurre,
Yet he ſpurres on. Now they are almost on him:
Now Titinius. Now ſome light: O he lights too.
Hee's tane. Showt.
And hearke, they ſhout for ioy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Come downe, behold no more:
O Coward that I am, to liue ſo long,
To ſee my best Friend tane before my face
Come hither ſirrah: In Parthia did I take thee Prisoner,
And then I ſwore thee, ſauing of thy life,
That whatsœuer I did bid thee do,
Thou ſhould'st attempt it. Come now, keepe thine oath,
Now be a Free-man, and with this good Sword
That ran through Caesars bowels, ſearch this bosome.
Stand not to anſwer: Heere, take thou the Hilts,
And when my face is couer’d, as ‘tis now,
Guide thou the Sword— Caesar, thou art reueng’d,
Euen with the Sword that kill’d thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pin.
SPEECH.LINE: So, I am free,
Yet would not ſo haue beene
Durst I haue done my will. O Caſſius,
Farre from this Country Pindarus ſhall run,
Where neuer Roman ſhall take note of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: It is but change, Titinius: for Octauius
Is ouerthrowne by Noble Brutus power,
As Caſſius Legions are by Antony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Titin.
SPEECH.LINE: These tydings will well comfort Caſſius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Where did you leaue him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Titin.
SPEECH.LINE: All disconsolate,
With Pindarus his Bondman, on this Hill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Is not that he that lyes vpon the ground?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Titin.
SPEECH.LINE: He lies not like the Liuing. O my heart!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Is not that hee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Titin.
SPEECH.LINE: No, this was he Meſſala,
But Caſſius is no more. O ſetting Sunne:
As in thy red Rayes thou doest ſinke to night;
So in his red blood Caſſius day is ſet.
The Sunne of Rome is ſet. Our day is gone,
Clowds, Dewes, and Dangers come; our deeds are done:
Mistrust of my ſucceſſe hath done this deed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistrust of good ſucceſſe hath done this deed.
O hatefull Error, Melancholies Childe:
Why do'st thou ſhew to the apt thoughts of men
The things that are not? O Error ſoone conceyu’d,
Thou neuer com'st vnto a happy byrth,
But kil'st the Mother that engendred thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tit.
SPEECH.LINE: What Pindarus? Where art thou Pindarus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Seeke him Titinius, whilst I go to meet
The Noble Brutus, thrusting this report
Into his eares; I may ſay thrusting it:
For piercing Steele, and Darts inuenomed,
Shall be as welcome to the eares of Brutus,
As tydings of this ſight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tit.
SPEECH.LINE: Hye you Meſſala,
And I will ſeeke for Pindarus the while:
Why did'st thou ſend me forth braue Caſſius?
Did I not meet thy Friends, and did not they
Put on my Browes this wreath of Victorie,
And bid me giue it thee? Did'st thou not heare their ſhowts?
Alas, thou hast misconstrued euery thing.
But hold thee, take this Garland on thy Brow,
Thy Brutus bid me giue it thee, and I
Will do his bidding. Brutus, come apace,
And ſee how I regarded Caius Caſſius:
By your leaue Gods: This is a Romans part,
Come Caſſius Sword, and finde Titinius hart.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Alarum. Enter Brutus, Meſſala, yong Cato, Strato, Volumnius, and Lucillius

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Where, where Meſſala, doth his body lye?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Lœ yonder, and Titinius mourning it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Titinius face is vpward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cato.
SPEECH.LINE: He is ſlaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: O Iulius Caesar, thou art mighty yet,
Thy Spirit walkes abroad, and turnes our Swords
In our owne proper Entrailes. Low Alarums.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cato.
SPEECH.LINE: Braue Titinius,
Looke where he haue not crown’d dead Caſſius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Are yet two Romans liuing ſuch as these? The last of all the Romans, far thee well: It is impoſſible, that euer Rome Should breed thy fellow. Friends I owe mo teares To this dead man, then you ſhall ſee me pay. I ſhall finde time, Caſſius: I ſhall finde time. Come therefore, and to Tharsus ſend his body, His Funerals ſhall not be in our Campe, Least it discomfort vs. Lucillius come, And come yong Cato, let vs to the Field, Labio and Flauio ſet our Battailes on: ‘Tis three a clocke, and Romans yet ere night, We ſhall try Fortune in a ſecond fight. Exeunt.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Alarum. Enter Brutus, Meſſala, Cato, Lucillius, and Flauius

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet Country-men: O yet, hold vp your heads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cato.
SPEECH.LINE: What Bastard doth not? Who will go with me?
I will proclaime my name about the Field.
I am the Sonne of Marcus Cato, hœ.
A Fœ to Tyrants, and my Countries Friend.
I am the Sonne of Marcus Cato, hœ.
And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus, I,
Brutus my Countries Friend: Know me for Brutus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: O yong and Noble Cato, art thou downe?
Why now thou dyest, as brauely as Titinius,
And may'st be honour’d, being Cato's Sonne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sold.
SPEECH.LINE: Yeeld, or thou dyest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Onely I yeeld to dye:
There is ſo much, that thou wilt kill me ſtraight:
Kill Brutus, and be honour’d in his death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sold.
SPEECH.LINE: We must not: a Noble Prisoner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Sold.
SPEECH.LINE: Roome hœ: tell Antony, Brutus is tane.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sold.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile tell thee newes. Heere comes the Generall,
Brutus is tane, Brutus is tane my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is hee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Safe Antony, Brutus is ſafe enough:
I dare aſſure thee, that no Enemy
Shall euer take aliue the Noble Brutus:
The Gods defend him from ſo great a ſhame,
When you do finde him, or aliue, or dead,
He will be found like Brutus, like himselfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: This is not Brutus friend, but I aſſure you, A prize no leſſe in worth; keepe this man ſafe, Giue him all kindneſſe. I had rather haue Such men my Friends, then Enemies. Go on, And ſee where Brutus be aliue or dead, And bring vs word, vnto Octauius Tent: How euery thing is chanc’d. Exeunt.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Brutus, Dardanius, Clitus, Strato, and Volumnius

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Come poore remaines of friends, rest on this
Rocke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clit.
SPEECH.LINE: Statillius ſhew’d the Torch-light, but my Lord
He came not backe: he is or tane, or ſlaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Sit thee downe, Clitus: ſlaying is the word,
It is a deed in fashion. Hearke thee, Clitus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clit.
SPEECH.LINE: What I, my Lord? No, not for all the World.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace then, no words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clit.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile rather kill my ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Hearke thee, Dardanius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dard.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I doe ſuch a deed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clit.
SPEECH.LINE: O Dardanius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dard.
SPEECH.LINE: O Clitus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clit.
SPEECH.LINE: What ill request did Brutus make to thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dard.
SPEECH.LINE: To kill him, Clitus: looke he meditates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clit.
SPEECH.LINE: Now is that Noble Veſſell full of griefe,
That it runnes ouer euen at his eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither, good Volumnius, list a word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſayes my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Why this, Volumnius:
The Ghoſt of Caesar hath appear’d to me
Two ſeuerall times by Night: at Sardis, once;
And this last Night, here in Philippi fields:
I know my houre is come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volum.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brut.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I am ſure it is, Volumnius.
Thou ſeest the World, Volumnius, how it goes,
Our Enemies haue beat vs to the Pit:
It is more worthy, to leape in our ſelues,
Then tarry till they push vs. Good Volumnius,
Thou know'st, that we two went to Schoole together:
Euen for that our loue of old, I prethee
Hold thou my Sword Hilts, whilest I runne on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vol.
SPEECH.LINE: That's not an Office for a friend, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cly.
SPEECH.LINE: Fly, flye my Lord, there is no tarrying heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell to you, and you, and Volumnius.
Strato, thou hast bin all this while asleepe:
Farewell to thee, to Strato, Countrymen:
My heart doth ioy, that yet in all my life,
I found no man, but he was true to me.
I ſhall haue glory by this loosing day
More then Octauius, and Marke Antony,
By this vile Conquest ſhall attaine vnto.
So fare you well at once, for Brutus tongue
Hath almost ended his liues History:
Night hangs vpon mine eyes, my Bones would rest,
That haue but labour’d, to attaine this houre.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Alarum. Cry within, Flye, flye, flye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cly.
SPEECH.LINE: Fly my Lord, flye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Hence: I will follow:
I prythee Strato, ſtay thou by thy Lord,
Thou art a Fellow of a good respect:
Thy life hath had ſome ſmatch of Honor in it,
Hold then my Sword, and turne away thy face,
While I do run vpon it. Wilt thou Strato?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stra.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me your hand first. Fare you wel my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bru.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell good Strato. — Caesar, now be ſtill,
I kill’d not thee with halfe ſo good a will.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Alarum. Retreat. Enter Antony, Octauius, Meſſala, Lucillius, and the Army

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: What man is that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: My Masters man. Strato, where is thy Master?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stra.
SPEECH.LINE: Free from the Bondage you are in Meſſala,
The Conquerors can but make a fire of him:
For Brutus onely ouercame himselfe,
And no man else hath Honor by his death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lucil.
SPEECH.LINE: So Brutus ſhould be found. I thank thee Brutus
That thou hast prou’d Lucillius ſaying true,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: All that ſeru’d Brutus, I will entertaine them.
Fellow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stra.
SPEECH.LINE: I, if Meſſala will preferre me to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: Do ſo, good Meſſala.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: How dyed my Master Strato?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stra.
SPEECH.LINE: I held the Sword, and he did run on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Octauius, then take him to follow thee,
That did the latest ſeruice to my Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: This was the Noblest Roman of them all:
All the Conspirators ſaue onely hee,
Did that they did, in enuy of great Caesar:
He, onely in a generall honeſt thought,
And common good to all, made one of them.
His life was gentle, and the Elements
So mixt in him, that Nature might ſtand vp,
And ſay to all the world; This was a man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Octa.
SPEECH.LINE: According to his Vertue, let vs vse him
Withall Respect, and Rites of Buriall.
Within my Tent his bones to night ſhall ly,
Mo’t like a Souldier ordered Honourably:
So call the Field to rest, and let's away,
To part the glories of this happy day.
